intro: Eschscholzia orcuttiana, commonly known as Orcutt's poppy, is a species of flowering plant native to the western United States. It is characterized by its striking red or orange flowers and feathery leaves. This annual plant typically grows in dry, rocky habitats and thrives in full sun. Its flowers bloom in late spring to early summer, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. The plant is part of the Papaveraceae family, which includes other well-known poppy species.
